YIKES! Okay, I fixed the spelling mistake! Sorry to anyone who printed it that way!

The MLK monument, posted by Graphicsforge, was beautiful. However, the full monument was a sizable. I wanted a model where Dr. King was distinguishable when printed smaller. I felt 'bust sized' might be more within the reach of 3D printers too. I took some creative license by moving the inscription up.

I used TinkerCAD for most of the final work, but I utilized Mesh Mixer for the first cut from the base; and I reduce of the geometry of the rock formation, so that more detail would be retained for the face and body...not sure if that was entirely successful or not.

description.text:
This is a spool-holder as promised in the title. The one i printed is made for carrying a spool with a diameter of 20 cm (or 8 inches for those who is not european).
I got this spool from a regular hardware store and is the kind that usually contains electrical wire. Hardware stores just throw these away, so just ask the clerk for one and there is a big chance you will get one.

Just print two of each part and mount the parts as shown in the pictures.
The spool-holder could just as well be plased on either sides of the makerbot as well.
Just attach the spool-holder by using som M3 screws that you have left over from building the makerbot.
If your spool is slightly bigger or smaller, just resize the files as needed with your favorite 3D software.

description.text: This is an improvement on the original Rest to reduce the amount of material used to print it, and enable them to be stacked for storage. Rests are used to hold woodwork pieces above a surface when they are being sprayed with lacquer.

comments.text: The rest would certaily damage a surface as  presently presented  if it was used to support a heavy piece. If the piece was positioned on the rests so that a seen surface was the surface of support, then supports such as these should not be used.In most  instances  I support the pieces on surfaces that will not be seen e.g. the bottom of the piece, and so any dents do not affect the appearance. In other instances the piece has legs and the piece is positioned on them. Once again, no problem if dents are made. The damade to light pieces wouldl also be minimal. I have yet to make any rests to this design, but was using it as an exercise to develop knowledge of designing in Autodesk 123D. If I strike any dent problems in use of the rests I will either cut the top off them to increase the supporting surface area, or redesign it. I have ordered a 3D Printer kit and will print some rests when it is set up. Thank you for you comments and suggestion.

title: Evolv DNA75 Box Mod Bottom Feeder v3 - Keystone 5209 Edition

description.text:
This is an evolution of mine other DNA75 bottom feeder box mod.
THIS BOX MOD work ONLY with keystone 5209 battery contact.

External size are: 52x25x85.

To complete u need:

  • a bottom feeder cap (u can choose body with 10 or 12 mm hole);
  • 8 magnets 3x2 mm;
  • 8 magnets 3x1 mm;
  • 2 keystone 5209 (http://fave.co/2bsgxvX);
  • some good wire (18 AWG http://fave.co/2iQRyBl);
  • 6 / 8.5 ml bottle;
  • 3 M2x5 or M1.6x5.

U can choose from two different fire button height (in the shot u can see the longest).

Deailet assembly tutorial here: http://www.esigblog.com/box-mod-dna75-bottom-feeder-v3-keystone-5209-edition
It's in italian, u can use google translator.

Suggested print setting:

  • layer 0,15;
  • support for the body;
  • infill 15/20%.

The shooted box mod is printed in ABS with Zortrax M200.

With the original Printrbot Simple 1401 Maker editions, the X & Y axis' movement was controlled by a string that was wrapped around the sanding tip of a Dremmel tool. Overtime with multiple use, these strings wear down and cause print shifting or eventual complete failure (which is what occurred to me). Due to this failure, I'd set out to firstly, patch up my printer such that it can print rudimentary parts to extend its life, with the goal of eventually converting to a reliable system of something other than string and sanding tool bits.

Shout out to jonlawrence, ahaer, and bringho for the inspiration for this upgrade.

This expansion started out as a simple last ditch effort to save the printer from breaking down. However, it has evolved into more than that, becoming a project with the aim of one, maximizing the bed area capable of being used by the printer while keeping the original aluminum print bed, and two, keeping design elements such as spring leveling and belt tensioning.

The first iteration of my print bed fix with the use of GT2 timing belts. A Frankenstein version of jonlawrence's design, original Printrbot balsa bed, zipties, and aluminum L-channel. Top view of the first prototype for bed design. Around 5 to 6 iterations in designs later... (left four is for the left X-axis piece, right are the right) A top view of the last two revisions of the current left side X-Axis bed holder. The one in the middle, ended up cracking at joint which was due to PLA's inflexibility and loss of moisture over time. The bottom most mount did not allow for a proper, full usage of the print bed area. From a side view, the evolution in design of the end stop limiter can be seen. The top most (most up to date) design implements a circular, slim shape that eliminates rubbing with the balsa wood side frames as the printer homes. Additionally, it also incorporates the indented end stop feature not present at the bottom most design, helping further optimize bed space usage.

Here is an ornament composed of ten tetrahedra whose vertices fall on the vertices of an imaginary dodecahedron.  
The compound of ten tetrahedra is well known.  The openSCAD code used was a modified version of the code used to calculate the compound of 5 cubes - thingiverse:31520 - Four Compounds of Cubes.  
A post with a hole to be used as a hanger was added.       .

The openSCAD output file was not closed.  It was repaired with netfabb Studio.  
A raft and external support are required for printing.  The stl file was printed on a Replicator using ReplicatorG.  The external support was easily removed leaving a nice print.

I have been wanting to make a genuine cyclone dust separator, but all the models I could find were either too small for my purposes, or too big to print. So, I modeled this guy so that it can be printed in pieces and glued together. I used the specifications in the first image (except it's about 3/8" shorter than it should be), since that seems to be the generally agreed upon parameters - per the laws of fluid dynamics (I don't really know, I just Googled it). Following those parameters made the model relatively tall, but it should give the best performance.

It is very much a WIP and I haven't printed it yet (mostly because I'm at the end of a role of PLA and the next roll is a different color...), but I can't think of any current problems.

I've included a hose adapter for the vacuum port that enters the spiral. it's designed specifically for a 2.5" hose end that comes with the hoses you buy at Home Depot for the Rigid Shop Vacs. I measured the inside diameter of that hose at 53.2mm, and this adapter is meant to fit inside of that hose snuggly (again, it hasn't been printed yet, so I haven't tested the fit considering my printer tolerances).

The dust inlet has a 2.5" ID and may still need an adapter.

I've included the Sketchup file so you can make changes as you see fit. Please let me know if you make improvements or find problems, since it'll be a little while before I'll have a good window to print it.

UPDATES:

1/13/17 - Fixed a geometric issue on the dust inlet that caused problems in the slicer. Re-uploaded Dust Inlet.STL, Upper Body Upper Half.STL, and Cyclone.SKP

print_settings.Notes:: We can't stress it enough -- for smooth operation, all the gears must be printed on a raft. These involute gears are designed with mathematical precision. If they are printed directly on a heated platform, they melt a little and no longer mesh well with each other.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/jNjbDgXy1e8

The Walking Gear Bot, through the clever use of planetary gearing, converts simple rotation to a walking motion. It uses a single 6V electric motor equipped with a speed reducer. This motor can be bought on eBay for less than $5. You will also need 4 AA batteries, a couple of jumper cables or wires, and a paperclip. No soldering required. See the video to watch this robot walk.

There are 11 involute gears in this mechanism, and 36 printed parts overall. Here is the full list of parts: quantities and filenames:

1 wg_motorholder.stl
2 wg_thumbscrew.stl
2 wg_leg.stl
2 wg_foot.stl
1 wg_pinion.stl
2 wg_gear36.stl
4 wg_gear24.stl
4 wg_gear16.stl
4 wg_bushing.stl
4 wg_bracket.stl
2 wg_rod.stl
4 wg_stoptube_short.stl
4 wg_stoptube_tall.stl

Hardware:

20 metric countersunk Phillips-head M3-12 screws.
2 metric M3 nuts.

Please visit http://www.otvinta.com/download08.html for detailed and illustrated assembly instructions.

WARNING: Adult supervision is recommended. While in operation, keep away from little children as their fingers can be caught in the moving parts and cause minor injuries.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

Yes

No

Notes:

We can't stress it enough -- for smooth operation, all the gears must be printed on a raft. These involute gears are designed with mathematical precision. If they are printed directly on a heated platform, they melt a little and no longer mesh well with each other.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/DqBOva04lcE" ></iframe>
The Walking Gear Bot is built around involute gears. We have created this video tutorial to show you how to design involute gears in Blender 3D. The robot uses five 16-tooth gears, four 24-tooth gears, and two 36-tooth gears.

This is a wrench holder that I designed for my 12pc set of raised panel craftsman wrenches.
In designing this I had a few goal in mind.
1) be able to print in one part with no supports needed
2) significantly decrease the space needed to hold a set of wrenches
3) be stronger than many others by adding fillets at the bottom of the pegs for better stress distribution
4) be able to read all the wrench sizes with relative ease
5) have the wrenches be very easily removed as this will remain in a toolbox

print_settings.Notes:: I used a brim on all the parts. I printed the case in cover in the orientation shown and as you would expect the surface on the fillets was poor. I deemed it acceptable as this will mostly be used in the dark . For the lights part, i changed from black to natural material after 4.2mm.

description.text:
This is a representation of the northern lights, not a very exact one of course. I printed it with black and natural PLA (clear may be better for the fins but natural worked well too) I then inserted 14 5mm LEDs which create the lighting effect. I used a TLC5940NT to contol the LEDs, connected to an arduino UNO. This allowed the brightness of each LED to be varied individually.

There are holes in the base piece to mount the arduino and copper strip board with the TLC5940 on it. They are designed for M3 6mm long screws. Everything can be powered over USB a usb cable or using the dc jack on the arduino. None of the LEDs draw more than 20ma so power draw is not an issue.

The lights part connects to the base by clipping in. There are little dimples in the slots on one side of the base. You may need to trim these back a bit to leave the parts fit together but this is easy to do. The case bit has holes to allow light out in a star like pattern. They sort of twinkle as the lights change or you walk past it.

Naturally, it looks much better in the dark!
https://youtu.be/m-pusYmGamA

I made a small change after printing and before uploading in that the fins now have a fillet. This is just to give them a little extra strength

description.text:
I looked briefly, for a clip on filament guide that could be pushed over the plastic frame of my reprap printer. I had just been guiding the filament over the frame and letting it drag but I wanted something. I found a couple of these but in all cases the slot was parallel to the hole in the guide and while that design might print better, tt does not work for me.

So I went into Tinkercad and built one.

This is not supposed to be pretty. I made the hole bid enough for 3d filament but the slot of top that comes blocked but can easily be knifed out is for 1.75mm filament.

The point is that there are two types of filament guides. One type has to be threaded while the other iind can have the filament inserted through the top and it then protects the filament and the printer edge from friction.

This guide will serve either purpose. For a threaded guide, clean it up and make sure the guide will clip on to the edge of the plastic. For the other kind of guide, just knife out the slot that is partially formed at the top of the guide.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

ABOUT 30%

Notes:

Print item on side with open slot viewable from top so that the direction of the strands strengthens the slot. Do not print with small end down. Rounded part requires support. I used CURA and specified support touching buildplate and brim.

The model of printer is actually reprapguru kit. But it would not allow me to pick other than the list.

After printing remove brim and support. I did my cleanup with a needlenose pliers. Pay attention to any stuff blocking the slot.

If you want to thread the filament through the round part, use it as it prints. If you want a top slot threaded guide, use an exacto knife to clean the partiially prepared angled slot in the top of the round filament guide.

title: CTC Prusa I3 Z-Axis Bracket replacement

description.text:
I needed a more solid Z-Axis bracket for my China made Prusa I3 (CTC), with a bigger hole for the end of the lead screw, to get rid of the vibrations. The original parts were made from ~5mm thick plywood.
It had also to be able to accommodate a ball bearing bracket (KFL08) for the end of the lead screw (but it should work even without one).
The design was made using 3D Studio Max and was exported as .stl. There are 3 versions, with different thickness: 5mm, 7mm and 9mm, each version having two distinct parts: for the right side and left one respectively.
Some very slight filing might be needed so as the Z-Axis smooth rod could fit perfectly into its hole.

comments.text:
My prints have a lot of wobble, I am thinking about replacing the original leadscrews.
Do you have a tutorial indicating the Marlin modifications due to the leadscrews replacement?
comments.author: Sigma95

comments.text:
Hi,
I myself changed the leadscrews on my printer, but I did not have to change anything within the code itself. The only thing I changed was the "steps per mm" parameter for Z axis, which is stored in the flash memory. You don't need to recompile the code to change this parameter. I changed it using Repetier-Host, from the menu "Config-> Firmare EEPROM Configuration". To find the right value, you can use an online calculator (i.e. http://www.prusaprinters.org/calculator/) or calculate it yourself...
It should be something like this (but you can find more accurate info on internet, of course) :
steps per revolution = 360/motor step angle (i.e. for 1.8 degrees angle -> steps /revolution =200), for 1:1 gear ratio
steps per mm = steps per revolution / leadscrew pitch (i.2. for 1.25mm pitch -> steps per mm = 160)
If your motors are set with microstepping, you should also multiply the result with the number of microsteps (i.e. for 1/16 microstepping, steps per mm = 160 * 16)
comments.author: Sigma95

comments.text:
Don't do the forcing of the z-threaded-rod into a bearing, what kind ever.
It rather produces wobble instead of fixing it.
The threaded rod is supposed to swing free.
The plain guiding rods are for positioning.
If you force both, it leads to interference.
Why do you think ALL originals have free threaded rods?
comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text:
I completely agree with you, I personally don't use any bearings myself. But there are people out there who seem to think otherwise, so if anyone wants to experiment, why not?
Anyway, the main reason for which I replaced the original was that the original had very small holes for the Z axis threaded rod and it was continuously touching the support making it vibrate and making noise. Not to mention that the original is made of weak 5mm plywood, which I don't like at all.
comments.author: McSchweg

title: Case for RD DPS3005 Power supply module
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Case for the RD DPS3005 switching mode power supply module. It's a great, compact and programmable CC/CV buck regulator that can output 0-30V / 0.5.1A with 1V dropout (available here) or their other similarly sized modules.

Figured it would be nice to make a clean build to carry at the field. Input is XT60 since I've standardized most of my power supplies and batteries with them for easy interconnection so I can hook it as much to a PSU and add it regulation/CC mode if it lacks it as to a battery. Output on combined 4mm banana and screw terminals that I've scavenged from a dead PSU... the pass through diameter is 8mm, may or may not fit your application.

UPDATED!
The new "hkconn" version is for these: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/female-4mm-electrical-binding-posts-12-24v-dc-50amp.html
Both versions now with easier to print vertical cooling slots and rounded corners.

title: Dual Blower Fan to 40mm Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple plate I designed to allow the use of two 50x15mm blower fans in place of the single 40mm fan used in the volcano cooler published by AK_Eric.

This is truly overkill. When I run the fans at full power, my volcano can't stay at temperature, even with insulation. The first time I tried it out my printer stopped extruding halfway through the first layer with cooling because the temperature of the hotend dropped below the "safe extrude" window. I've been running it at 10-25% for an open printer, but I designed this for printing in an enclosure.

On a D-Bot, the fans need to be oriented horizontally, with one blower drawing air up from above the heatbed and one drawing air down. You could theoretically put in a switch to change the source of air (E.G. to use warm air for cooling ABS parts or cool air for PLA), but I have both fans wired in parallel.

I printed mine to have a snug enough fit to hold the fans in position with friction alone, but decided to put a bit of super glue on to seal the deal. Your results may vary.

This should fit any 40mm fan that needs more power. WAY more power.

comments.text: Note on the crazy cooling power: I used to have a similar problem with my volcano nozzle cooling too fast when the fan was on full blast. As it turned out, they had shipped me a lower wattage heater cartridge (20w): When I got a more powerful one (40w), and re-pid tuned the setup, the problem went away: I can run it at full blast with no loss of nozzle temp. Food for thought. I blogged about it here: http://www.akeric.com/blog/?p=3673
comments.author: AK_Eric

comments.text: I checked the resistance and calculated the power of my heater, and it should be around 34-35 watts, but it was sold as a 40w cartridge. I've got the 24V model and I've been considering swapping in a 12v low wattage one for the extra power.

remixed_from.title: Very simple printable spool mount for MendelMax

description.text:
This is a reinforced version of Phaiax's spool mount. It can be easily mounted on the MendelMax 1.5, or any printer based on aluminium extrusion.  
I had a spool too big to fit his mount, and it actually broke the support. So I made a stronger version with 3 arms, and angled supports.  
Side arms have a hole included to allow a screwdriver to pass.  
The scad file included is mostly parametric, and can be used to change the spool radius, length, the supports, the hole sizes, ...
Print the support with your usual parameters. No scaling required.

Wanted something nice to store my glue sticks, as I swear by them for bed adhesion! Printed at .2mm layer, .4mm nozzle. Should have printed layers at .12 or .16, but didn't want to wait the extra time. Turned out nice regardless. I printed standing, with supports to start the front and back faces only, the circles were unsupported. Printed with Orange ABS. Pla may print nicer, you can see a few minor flaws from a tiny warp on the sides and some sags on the tops of some large circles. Overall I'm happy with the design and print, and it works well hung or freestanding :)

title: Briggs and Stratton Air filter Adapter

description.text:
I have a Fun Power Briggs and Stratton 5 Horsepower (Hp) engine for a go kart, I bought the air filter you see in the picture and it is the wrong type. My carburetor has two screws on the sides, but the air filter is for the type with the screw in the middle. I made this model so I can attach this without buying a new air filter. (Please note this is one of the first models I made so feedback would be gratefully requested)

Edit: Print was perfect. One thing I needed to do was to drill the two side screw hole just a tad bigger, just so the screw head could fit into the hole.

description.text:
This is a zip toggle I designed to replace the one that broke on my jacket. I have seen a lot of replacement zippers here on Thingiverse and even tried a few but they were never strong enough. Paperclip based ones rusted and broke and ones with a plastic loop snapped too easily.

This one uses an arm stolen from a bulldog clip. This is much sturdier and easier to fit.

  • Just squeeze the arm together to release it from the clip.
  • Thread through the remains of the zipper.
  • Squeeze the arm together and fit the printed toggle.

Easy.

Hopefully this will be useful to others. I have made this a customizer compatible thing so that the dimensions can be altered to your liking.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with both ABS and PLA, using 0.2mm layer height and 0.4mm nozzle. ABS and PLA can be mixed - the picture shows the harness made from PLA (green) and the text using ABS (blue). You have to modify the temperatures accordingly if you mix materials.

description.text:
My mom keeps her Nexus in her handbag and uses a lanyard to find it quickly when it rings. I made this simple harness so she can attach the lanyard without having to use a full phone case.

While the .scad and .stl files show a blank back, the photo shows that the holder can be customized with text. I only have a single extruder on my printer, but the text can be produced by switching the filament twice. The necessary code is present in the .scad file, as are the instructions. Bear in mind that you'll have to split the gcode into three files and do a fairly minimal editing.

I place no restrictions on the use of this code - you are welcome to do what you like with it.

I printed this with both ABS and PLA, using 0.2mm layer height and 0.4mm nozzle. ABS and PLA can be mixed - the picture shows the harness made from PLA (green) and the text using ABS (blue). You have to modify the temperatures accordingly if you mix materials.

Cleanup

Depending on your print quality, you might have to clean up the overhangs and edges a bit with an utility knife.

author: TheMagicalC

title: Low Profile Ball-Bearing Printbot Simple Metal Spool Holder

description.text:
A very smooth running nearly frictionless spool holder with a low-profile and fast built time. This is designed to sit atop the z-axis guides on a PrintBot Simple Metal. It also requires 4x ball bearing (608ZZ) as found on most printers, skateboards, rollerblades, etc. No other hardware is required, the ball bearings snap into the design.

I've been using @References3D spool holder for over a year and just recently started getting some binding issues with a new brand of filament. While the design attached is a complete re-design, you can definitely spot the inspiration from "PrintrBot simple metal's spool holder".

comments.text: I have the Z-axis upgrade for the Printrbot, and my current spool holder sits vertically atop the printer, making it awfully top heavy. So I loved the idea of a horizontal spool holder to lower the center of gravity a bit.

title: Anet A8 X belt tensioner upgrade

description.text:
This is an X belt tensioner that does not require you to go out and buy a new length of belt like all the rest.
This upgrade was built to only use extra parts given with the Anet A8 kits

+Attach it to the back of the extruder carriage with two m3 x 18 screws.

+press one end of the belt into the belt holder with a flat head skew driver. I used a small flat head to spread the jaws on the holder then pushed the belt in. the fit is meant to be very tight!

+use a M3 x 30 screw and m3 nut to pull the two assemblies togeather

print_settings.Notes:: This should be able to run on practically any printer. Raft is optional, but the supports will extend past the base. Since this lives inside a microphone body, overall resolution and appearance is up to the maker. The M2.5 clearance holes will have to be opened up to full size if your printer under-sizes holes. Supports are imperative for the lower arms of the figure-8 capsules to print correctly.

description.text:
This is a printable microphone saddle and post to accompany Jules Ryckenbusch's Instructable for making a self-contained mid-side microphone:

http://www.instructables.com/id/Build-the-MS-Alice-Stereo-Microphone/

I documented my build here:

https://tombenedict.wordpress.com/2016/11/11/building-the-ms-alice-microphone-part-1/
https://tombenedict.wordpress.com/2016/11/23/building-the-ms-alice-microphone-part-2/

I printed mine at Shapeways, but since then I purchased a 3D printer of my own and printed a second one at home.

This will fit the mounting hole pattern of the Neewer NW-800 microphone body, but should fit many other BM-800 microphones as well. It is designed specifically for the Transsound TSB-165A capsule Jules used in his article. If you choose to use some other capsule, you will need to re-design the part.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

This should be able to run on practically any printer. Raft is optional, but the supports will extend past the base. Since this lives inside a microphone body, overall resolution and appearance is up to the maker. The M2.5 clearance holes will have to be opened up to full size if your printer under-sizes holes. Supports are imperative for the lower arms of the figure-8 capsules to print correctly.

I absolutely hated the provided spool holders that came with the Prusa i3 MK2 so decided to spice up the aesthetics and make it a bit more functional with a crossbar to hold the filament. All spool sizes should be compatible.

I wanted to test captive nuts while printing so the arms connect to the cylinders via embedded M3 nuts and secured using 15mm M3 bolts. I've provided a guide on how to pause the print to add the nuts.

I've also provided a combined .stl for those that don't want to use hardware.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40-60%
• Pausing prints

Adding a pause to the gcode

You need to embed the M3 screws while it's printing so this requires a pause to be placed into the .gcode. I use Simplify3D and this can be done in the scripts tab of the process options. Using 0.2mm z-resolution we want to pause at around layer 29 to insert the nut, so the script to use:

{REPLACE "\n; layer 29, Z = " "; layer 29\nG1 X190.000000 Y5.000000\nM25\nM17\nG1 X190.000000 Y5.000000\n; layer 29 "}

This will place the following into the .gcode file (I've commented what happens but this is not in the .gocde):

layer 29 //start layer 29
G1 X190.000000 Y190.000000 //Go to the back right of the bed
M25 //Pause SD card print
M17 //Enable the motors so we don't move the bed when getting the nuts in the holes.
G1 X190.000000 Y190.000000 //I honestly don't know why this is here.

If you don't have Simplify3D I am sure the other slicers can do something similar but I have no idea how, but you can do it manually in the .gcode. This is an example of what it should look like (G1 commands will be different for you so don't stress if it looks different):

G1 X103.797 Y103.000 E0.0263
G1 X103.997 Y103.000 F1920
G1 E-1.5000 F1800; layer 29
G1 X190.000000 Y5.000000
M25
M17
G1 X190.000000 Y5.000000
; layer 29 2.9
G1 E10 F50
; inner perimeter
G1 X104.541 Y120.533 F4800
G1 Z2.900 F1000

Save the .gcode file and we're almost done...

Simplify3D Script Settings Adding a purge to the gcode

One thing this script fails to do is to purge the nozzle after the pause. This means the nozzle is left in a retracted state when it goes to print the outer perimeters of the next layer. So let's jump into the .gcode file (wherever you saved it) and add one more line.

Find the "layer 29" and go to where you can see the code above. The place we want to edit will look something like:

; layer 29 2.9
; inner perimeter
G1 X104.541 Y120.533 F4800

Add the following: G1 E10 F50 (extrude 10mm at a feedrate of 50mm/s) just after the layer line:

; layer 29 2.9
G1 E10 F50
; inner perimeter
G1 X104.541 Y120.533 F4800

What your gcode should look like Printing

  1. Make sure the cylinders print with the hexagonal ends up the top and the arms print with the small M3 cap hole on the bottom. The cylinders need support from the build platform only and should have the supports INSIDE the M3 hole of the male part removed. The arms should have supports for the M3 cap hole on the bottom.

  2. The print will pause at layer 29 and move the back edge of the bed.

  3. PUSH the nuts in the holes, be sure to remove any supports in the holes and MAKE SURE THE NUTS DO NOT EXTEND OUTSIDE OF THE HOLES otherwise the nozzle will hit them.

  4. Hit resume print on the LCD. The nozzle will purge a small amount and then continue to print. The next layer probably won't be very nice as it'll be bridging a solid layer but it'll fix itself up ;)

Done!

Inserting nuts while the print is paused
Print with the cylinders pointing up and no supports and you're good to go!

description.header: Best practice for mounting the spool
description.text:
The way I use this is as follows:

  1. Get your spool and insert one of the arms of the holder into the spool.
  2. Put the other arm into the other side of the spool and connect the arms together.
  3. Pick up the spool + holder, keeping it all together and attach both arms to the top of the frame at the same time. Be sure the spool is hanging towards the back of the printer, otherwise the extruder can hit it.

description.text:
I fell in love with the Gyroid structure, and wanted to make something special out of it.

I think Sappho's Head is one of the most beautiful Model I know of, and wanted to make something special out of it. Hope you will like it just as I do.

The infill pattern is made in Netfabb Basic, it's a bit labour intensive but I think it worth it.

You can print the Gyroid infill on its own, but you will have to be careful with your support placement, because from the inside there is no way to get the support out.

title: Single Action Rubber Band Cowboy Pistol
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Trying to learn how to make a working single action mechanic for another project I am working on, I found the plans to make a wooden single action pistol here - https://www.rbguns.com/guns/single-action-army-revolver/

I converted it to be printable. It actually works. I printed the pin pieces at 100% infill. I wish I had printed them laying down instead of standing up because the catch pieces pin broke and after gluing the body pieces together I can't replace it now.

Uses 40mm rubberbands. Use Three for the Hammer to the handle, and one for the trigger to the toggle.

I think I figured out a way to add the single action mechanism to a more accurate colt single action prop I am working on so stay tuned for that as well.

See a video here: https://youtu.be/3qKsrjJteoo

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha / Flash Forge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 Micron

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Assembly can be tricky, look at the pictures to see how the components go. The frame has to be glued together, along with the grips, and the barrel and sights. Some sanding might be needed.

comments.text: Great design and works very well. Next print I'll make it a bit smaller so my kids can use it easier - it's quite big in the hand. I've got all the pins glued in to one side only and it snaps together fine, but I can open it up to replace broken pins or internal bands if necessary. Very fun and my biggest print project so far (I'm only 2 weeks into 3D printing). Cheers!

description.text:
!!!!!! as of now the only Rim that works is v5! i will fix all of them as soon as i can !!!!!!!

This is a adapter for the OpenRC tires. There are two rims in the files, (both from OpenRC "Palmiga_ORC_rim6_V2_stronger"

  1. A small rim (1/16) with correct hex size (12mm) because if you just resize the whole Rim it would be two small to fit on the 12mm shaft. With this rim you can resize the OpenRC wheels to .625 and they will fit on the rim.

  2. A 1:10 sized rim (default) with rim extenders, the rim extenders create more length between the R/C and the wheel so they can turn, you can put 1:10 wheels on a 1:16 and still be able to move the wheels). The Hex/shaft and outer rim are included if you would like to make the spacing longer/shorter.
    (print with touching bed support)
    For more information message me. Thanks!

This is still a work in progress

description.text:
This is a printable microphone saddle and post to accompany Jules Ryckenbusch's Instructable for modifying a cheap LCD condenser microphone:

http://www.instructables.com/id/Modify-a-cheap-LDC-Condenser-microphone/

I documented my build here:

https://tombenedict.wordpress.com/2016/10/09/bm-800-microphone-conversion-part-1/
https://tombenedict.wordpress.com/2016/10/22/bm-800-microphone-conversion-part-2/

I machined the original out of aluminum, but after printing a capsule saddle for the mid-side version of this microphone, I realized a 3D printed saddle for this project would work just as well.

This will fit the mounting hole pattern of the Neewer NW-800 microphone body, but should fit many other BM-800 microphones as well. It is designed specifically for the Transsound TSB-2555B capsule Jules used in his article. If you choose to use some other capsule, you will need to re-design the part.

Supports:

No

Notes:

This prints fine without a raft, and supports are unnecessary. I printed mine with a 45% infill, but it should work fine with less.

Since this part lives inside a microphone, print quality, resolution, and overall aesthetics are up to the maker.

If your printer tends to under-size holes, you will have to open up the M2.5 clearance holes on the base.

comments.text: What are the measurements for the base plate?
comments.author: ellisgl

comments.text: The base plate is designed to fit on a BM-700 or BM-800 microphone, or any of the variants. The holes are arranged on a 10mmx15mm rectangle.

description.text: This mount was made for the QAV and QAV clone frames. But it is super easy to modify and adjust to fit just about any flat top frame. I wanted something better than cheap looking foam, but just as light, something that can hold up in a crash but give a little in small bumps. Coming in only at 2.8 grams, this is on par with a piece of lose wobbly, hard to level your cam, crap foam. I also added just enough of a cavity under the print to add double sided sticky tape or a bead of hot glue to get this to stick down. Now just drop your cam on and strap it in for a ripping of a life time. This thing works like a dream if you print at my recommended settings. I highly recommend TPU for this. It's a must, and super cheap on amazon, well worth the money.

author: vwclogan

description.text:
I recently volunteered as a test subject for a practice bike fit. Although I benefitted from the cleat wedges they installed, they cost $20, which is far beyond their manufacturing cost.

So I made these.

1 degree incline, with a thin & thick edge.

There are STLs for a single one, plus a three-wedge assembly.

Never tested. I don't recommend installing these unless you know what you're doing or a qualified bike fitter suggests them. Responsibility is yours if you mess up your joints/body by misusing these.

Thin edge is 0.40 mm, thick edge is 1 mm. Based on measurements of the BikeFit red SPD cleat wedges.

Here are the originals: https://www.amaincycling.com/bike-fit-systems-cleat-wedges-for-spd-pedals-1220802/p318703

I used the green wedge image as a template for a trace. I scaled it by referencing the slot in the BikeFit red cleat wedges, which came out to be constrained inside a rectangle of 8 mm width by 27 mm length.

I used lines & splines to complete one side, then mirrored the result. Extruded, then cut-extrude to leave behind a 0.40 mm thin edge, then a 1 degree incline to the other side. This left 1.003 mm, which is close enough to 1 mm for me.

The extrusion sketch doesn't actually matter too much as long as the entire cleat is sitting on the edge, which I believe to be the case.

I made the three-wedge assembly because printing 3 separate 1 degree wedges, then stacking them will not give the same angle due to imprecision inherent to 3D printers. I also need them personally.

I maxed out the gauge here (https://www.amazon.com/Bike-Fit-Forefoot-Measuring-Device/dp/B005Z177AA) at around 20 degrees or so, & in the 60 seconds I tried the cleat on, it made a huge difference. The three-wedge STL may be irrelevant to you, & I'd be surprised if you needed multiples of it.

Reference Image

Print multiple & stack them depending on what your (qualified) fitter tells you.

Depending on how many you use, you may need longer bolts to avoid stripping threads at the female plate in the shoe.

People complained about the actual red BikeFit cleat wedges, saying that the necessary torque to adequately secure the wedges would crush the wedges, negating any angle they may have shimmed.

In practice, it definitely did look like the plastic yielded a lot. With enough of them (I got 3 on each cleat), the net angle was still there, though it will certainly not be purely additive.

I am concerned that the 3D printed material (HIPS, PLA, ABS, etc.) will crack under the considerable compression under the two bolts. Not tight enough, & you may lift your foot & find the cleat still stuck in the pedal, or just lose the cleat entirely somewhere on the road (you'll probably never find it).

I have not yet tested it, so if you beat me to it, please let me know how it goes.

I developed this because in previous experience, the rafters/brim I've seen seem like they could take the stress, because they weren't printed the same way as the actual target structure. Here's to hoping I was right.

Depending on your printer, you may not have the resolution to render a layer height of 0.40 mm, which could screw up the print & yield a single thickness. I'm not sure, but please correct me if this is actually a non-issue.

13 Jan 17: Not tested. Use at your own risk & report the results.

15 Jan 17: Printed a few off. I forgot to mess with the layer height settings (minimize them). I'm going to try them anyways. The 1 degree wedges had 2 layers, the 3-wedge assemblies came out with 4 layers. Checking with calipers, it was very close to the designed thin & thick thicknesses. Now we'll see if they crack under compression.

16 Jan 17: Mounted the 3-wedge ones last night, but the bolts were too short to reach. I tried two singles on each side, & the bolts barely reached. Highly recommend getting longer bolts. I just did about 10 miles, & they haven't cracked or anything. The cleats felt pretty secure, though 2 singles isn't enough for me.

3-wedge on the left, single on the right. Thickness view of the single wedge. Thickness view of the 3-wedge assembly.

Easy Photo Rig

Easy Photo Rig provides an easy way to take great videos of yourself or others without the need for a tripod or any special equipment. Just your phone and a measuring stick (such as a yard-stick, meter-stick, or drywall square.)

Instructions
  1. Measure your phone and measuring stick in mm.
  2. Customize using Customizer.
  3. Print 2 of them.
  4. Put them on the phone, and slide it onto the measuring stick.
  5. Put your measuring stick between two of something, like two ladders or two bookshelves.
  6. Take lots of great videos with it.

The design is customizeable OpenSCAD so you can adjust the parameters to fit your needs. (The default measurements will fit a Nexus 5x with a case on it, and a 2x48 inch drywall square.)

I needed a way to mount my phone to shoot YouTube videos. I bought a tiny phone tripod, but all it did was fall over under the weight of the phone, not to mention the camera is on the far end of it, making it a pain to keep it level.

If you'd like to see some footage shot with the Easy Photo Rig, head on over to my YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/c/steveweber314

Do you have any idea how many of these I went through when I was repairing and installing washers?
A lot, lol. Whirlpool/Maytag never wanted to put metal sleeves inside this part. It was made to
essentially be a sheer pin of sorts, a sacrificial plastic piece that would break if the drive was

intended torque threshold. So, they were forced to make it stronger.

author: OnShape

description.text: rescale to 40% for minifig

A Clever New Fidget for the Sophisticated Fidgeter

  • Print in 30 minutes or less.
  • As little as 6 grams of filament.
  • Fidget with your left hand, right hand, or both.
  • Just the right size and shape to spin satisfyingly in your hand, unlike those other big, heavy spinners that can be frustratingly difficult to use.
  • Fits in any pocket.
  • Finish it smooth or rough it up, you decide.
  • Infinite color combination options.
  • Print lots of them at once.
  • No bearings
  • No moving parts.
  • No rafts.
  • No supports.
  • No infill (some infill is recommended to give it a little more heft, but its not necessary in order to print it.)

Added Bonus - Fidget Stone/Worry Stone combo

If you choose the "Download All Files" button today, you'll not only get the amazing fidget stone, but you'll also receive the worry stone at absolutely no extra charge.

Sand down any rough edges. I like to give the whole thing a good sanding to get it nice and smooth. Then you can hit it with a heat gun, vapor wash, or your favorite epoxy coating if you desire. I personally prefer it with a little bit of a roughed up texture.

Don't Forget to Post Your Makes!

I've always been a fidgeter. Certain objects I will just pick up and naturally fidget with. A pen for example, I will pick it up and spin the cap around endlessly.

But my go-to fidget is when I take a small object, like a USB drive for example, place it between my thumb and middle finger, and spin it with my ring and index finger. This is the purpose for which I have designed this fidget. The indentations in the middle keep it firmly in place, even when spinning at blazing speeds upwards of 3 to 4 rotations per second.

I tried some of the fidget spinners out there and I just didn't find them satisfying. They didn't scratch the fidget itch for me, so to speak. I went through roughly a dozen prototypes, honing the size and shape of this fidget to meet my particular fidgeting style.

This fidget may not work for you, but for less than 6 grams of filament and 30 minutes of your time,what have you got to lose?

I wanted this fidget to have an organic feel, like a piece of stone or wood. I like to change filaments during the print to create the look of laminated wood.

After creating the original, it was suggested by a fellow fidgeter that a 'worry stone' style would be useful. The worry stone has a thumb shaped indentation favorable to rubbing rather than spinning.

print_settings.Notes:: You need one top and one bottom for each corner.

title: Heated Bed Stabilizers for Monoprice Maker Select v2.1 (Wanhao i3)

description.text:
Problem:

The stock heated bed on the Monoprice Maker Select v2.1 (and probably other Wanhao i3 variants) very easily slides around a mm or two in each direction in relation to the Y carriage plate. This causes noticeable layer shifts in the X and Y axis from the slightest bump to the heated bed during printing.

Solution:

These heated bed stabilizers "hug" the bed screws to prevent them from wiggling around in the larger carriage plate holes. The springs and thumbscrews act together to squeeze the stabilizers in a sandwich against the carriage plate, providing enough friction to keep the screws from shifting along the X and Y axis.

Other mods

This Thing is part of a set of mods I've designed for this printer - here's the rest of the set, I hope you find them useful:

  • Bracket for Thorped's fan duct
  • Cold fan end shroud

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm/layer

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Items to print:

Qty. 4 - bed_stabilizer_top
Qty. 4 - bed_stabilizer_bottom

You need one top and one bottom for each corner.

To assemble, you'll need to remove the all the thumbscrews from the heated bed and lift up each corner (you don't have to completely remove the heated bed from the carriage plate).

You then want to create a sandwich at each corner, like this:

Heated bed
Spring
Top printed part
Aluminum y-carriage plate
Bottom printed part
Thumbscrew/wingnut

After you reassemble all the corners, it's very important to fully compress and release all four corners of the heated bed repeatedly until the corners travel relatively smoothly within the limits of the springs and thumbscrews. The idea is to loosen up the holes in the printed parts just enough to permit the bed to move if the extruder pushes against it due to a Z-axis problem.

I was trying to successfully print four y-axis bearing brackets (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1375534) and just could not get a set to print without layer shifts of some kind that would have thrown off the bearing bracket alignment. This led me to try and track down why.

As it turns out, I print exclusively in PETG, which means I get occasional large blobs, particularly on infill (still working on tweaking slicer settings). When the print head bumped these blobs it would shift the entire heated bed in relation to the Y carriage, causing these layer shifts. I developed this mod to fix this problem.

Note that I originally designed this mod with the intention of supergluing the top and bottom halves together, creating a nice extra squeeze against the carriage plate. After doing a test fit, though, it solved the problem without the extra step of gluing it, so that's how I've published it.

Source file from DesignSpark Mechanical (.rsdoc) is included in the file list.

description.text: I remixed a members filament holder to fit the A3 and have had pretty good success but no matter how well I tuned my printer I kept getting minor inconsistencies.. I finally figured out it was because the spool was being jerked sometimes during fast travel or at the end of the bed. I looked it up and a lot of large format printers have tubing running from the spool entry to the direct drive extruder and they call it reverse bowden. I created this in tinkercad https://tinkercad.com/things/ltjbhRIq9jZ feel free to download it and mess with it.. I named it V6 as that is as many times as it took me to get it right. It clips pretty tight to the top and snaps around the back of the bottom of the upper frame rail. I wanted it like this so it would be movable depending on what spool I am using at the time.

I tried many available designs from those with bearings that like to unwind the spool on their own. To 3 and four piece designs that required assembly with screws or snap together. I never was really satisfied with any of them because one would work x brands of spools ok but not other and so on.

I thought I would design a simple one piece spool holder that is printed in one shot. Spool holders don't need bearings, the spool slides smoothly on the printed plastic. Besides you want to have a little static friction or your spool will unwind and tangle. I designed this spool holder to fit all of my spools of filament from small spindles to large, from wide to narrow and should fit 98% of spools out there. Simple one handed loading allow use of the other hand to hang on to the loose end of the filament.

See my Spool Keeper accessory for this holder here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2036770

See my Filament Guide for this spool holder here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2038850

The spool is the same dimensions as my Wanaho Duplicator 6 Spool Holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2002418

Updates:
V3 - Changed reduced the accessory mounting holes to give 3mm screws more bite.

comments.text: This is definitely the best spool holder out there. Simple, 1 piece, stable and easy to print.

description.text:
Sorry for the poor photos. This is a 27mm quick fill funnel. What makes it quick? Not just the size of the funnel but it provides a way to let the air escape while you pour liquid into the funnel. Because the walls are 1.6mm thick you could scale it down to 50% it's original size and still have a working funnel. Scaling it up shouldn't be a problem.

NOTE: PLA will warp when it gets too warm. Don't use a dishwasher or very hot water to clean it. 3D prints are not deemed food safe. I am not responsible for any health issues related to the use off this funnel for food preparation.

MakerBot

100%

Notes:

No raft required

Gently push the raft off with your thumbs by applying pressure on it and pushing it away from the funnel. Put a sheet off sandpaper on a flat surface and drag the surface where the raft used to be over it to create a clean flat surface.

description.text:
In the original design, the ocarina was cutted in a half (and his flat sides wasn't totally flat), so you had to print them separately and glue it, also, the ring with the triforce hasn't a flat surface, and that makes it difficult to print. as well, the triforce logo was in the wrong side of the ring.

In this remix the ocarina is now in just two pieces (the ocarina, and the ring with the triforce)
the triforce logo is now on both sides of the ring, front and back. and it have a flat surface to make it easier to print.

What I recommend is to print the ocarina rotated to 53 degrees in Y (you can see the example in the images), I also moved the ocarina like 1mm in Z and added supports, in this way it will be printed all over supports.
NOTE: The ring doesn't need any supports

You can see the actual mesures in the images.

And yes, it works. have a nice print!

description.text:
A spool keeper for my one piece spool holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2036761
And my Duplicator 6 spool holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2002418

It allows you to give the spool more drag to keep a pesky spool from tangling up. The holder contains a clip that you flex like a clothespin when installing on the spool holder.

Print in a rigid but flexible material like ABS, PETG, or possibly a modified PLA+. If printed in standard PLA the clip will most likely break (and possibly explode across room) when attempting to flex clip.

description.text:
Pair of STL files for generation of extendable leadscrew that you can make to any length, simply by printing more of them on a 3d printer.

Ideal for lathe or mill projects where you just don't wanna pay.
